concept.title: Column Family and Field Mappings
concept.shortdesc: When you configure the Google Bigtable destination, you map record fields to Google Cloud Bigtable columns. You define the Cloud Bigtable columns to write to by defining the column family and column qualifier.

conbody.p: Google Bigtable destinationcolumn familycolumn familyGoogle BigtableGoogle Bigtable destinationfield mappingsYou can specify a default column family to use for all columns, or you can explicitly define the column family for each field mapping using the following format: <column family>:<qualifier>. Use the default or the explicit column family mapping based on the following scenarios:

dlentry.dt: All columns belong to the same column family
dlentry.dd: When all columns written to the table belong to the same column family, you can enter a default column family, clear the Explicit Column Family Mapping property, and then enter only the qualifier when you map fields to columns. When you enter a default column family and clear the Explicit Column Family Mapping, any column family defined in a field to column mapping is ignored. The destination always uses the default column family.

For example, to map record fields to the Cloud Bigtable columns cf:a, cf:b, and cf:c, enter cf as the default column family. Clear Explicit Column Family Mapping, and then in the field to column mapping, define the columns using only the qualifier, like so: a, b, c.
The following image shows the destination configured to use a default column family for all columns:

dlentry.dt: Columns belong to different column families
dlentry.dd: When columns written to the table belong to different column families, do not enter a default column family. Instead, select the Explicit Column Family Mapping property, and then enter the column family and qualifier when you map fields to columns using the following format: <column family>:<qualifier>.

For example, to map record fields to the Cloud Bigtable columns cf1:a, cf1:b, and cf2:a, do not enter a value for the default column family. Select Explicit Column Family Mapping, and then in the field to column mapping, define the columns using the <column family>:<qualifier> format, like so: cf1:a, cf1:b, cf2:a.
The following image shows the destination configured to explicitly define the column family for each field mapping:

dlentry.dt: Columns belong to different column families, but youâ€™d like to use a default value for a group of columns
dlentry.dd: When columns written to the table belong to different column families, you can use a default column family for a group of columns. Then, you can override the default for some of the columns by selecting the Explicit Column Family Mapping property. When you map fields to columns, enter only the qualifier to use the default column family. Enter the column family and qualifier using the format <column family>:<qualifier> to override the default column family.

For example, to map record fields to the Cloud Bigtable columns cf1:a, cf1:b, and cf2:a, enter cf1 for the default column family. Select Explicit Column Family Mapping so that you can override the default column family. Then in the field to column mapping, define the columns like so, using the <column family>:<qualifier> format to override the default column family: a, b, cf2:a.
